The meaning is that the scale value multiplied by the number by the 
arrow =
is the rate at which the chosen element (e.g. O) is "flowing" 
from one spe=
cies to another due to chemistry. For example, for a 
reaction like

COOH +=
 M <=3D> CO + OH

the COOH -> OH arrow and the COOH -> CO arrow would both =
have a weight 
equal to the reaction forward rate of progress, since one O =
atom goes 
to each. The total weight is the sum over all reactions connecti=
ng the 
two species.

The situation is more complex when two reactants and =
two products have 
the element being traced, for example:

OH + H2O2 <=3D> =
HO2 + H2O

Which reactant does the O in H2O come from?

This reaction could=
 describe an H abstraction:
      (O-H) + (H)(O2-H) =3D (O-H)(H) + (O2-H)

=
or it could describe an O abstraction:
      (O-H) + (O)(O-H2) =3D (O-H)(O)=
 + (O-H2)

In the first case, H2O should be connected to OH in an O-atom re=
action 
path diagram, and in the second case it should be connected to H2O2=
.  
Cantera makes the choice by default so that the "transferred species" 
=
is the lightest. In this case, it will choose the H abstraction 
alternativ=
e, since H is lighter than O. It is possible in principle to 
specify for e=
ach reaction the "groups" that rearrange in the reaction - 
i.e. which bond=
s break - and override Cantera's default.  But actually 
the CTI file speci=
fication does not yet implement this. In any case, a 
file rxnpath.log is w=
ritten every time a reaction path diagram is 
generated listing all ambiguo=
us reactions and the one Cantera chooses.

A long answer, but there it is..=
. hope it helps.

Dave
